_exec_summary.SummaryText:
-Introduction to Risk Management Program-



A Risk Management Program (RMP) has been developed for the UNFI facility in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania.  The Risk Management Plan for the UNFI Harrisburg facility has been prepared for the storage and use of anhydrous ammonia in the facility's refrigeration system.  Each part of the RMP is submitted to the Environmental Protection Agency, meeting or exceeding the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.  



The submission is due to the need to fulfill the requirements mandated by the EPA that a new submission or an update should occur in the event of a change in ammonia inventory. A new freezer process was added to the facility increasing the total ammonia inventory.



-Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response or Emergency Action Policies-



The UNFI Harrisburg facility recognizes management's responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment and property.  The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The controls of accidents have been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the UNFI Harrisburg facility.



To accomplish the company's goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established an Emergency Action Plan.  The objectives of the Emergency Action Plan are to: maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering and the economic burden resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.



One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response or action programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard and EPA's Risk Management Program regulation.  Allen Slagle, the General Manager, is responsible for implementation of the Risk Management Program.



The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emerg

ency response or emergency action programs is to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses, environmental impact and avoid physical property damage.



The accidental release prevention and emergency response or emergency action programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures and practices which govern individual processes, activities or pieces of equipment.  These rules are detailed and are improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to and accepted by all employees at the facility.



-Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled-



The UNFI Harrisburg facility includes three ammonia refrigeration systems (The Refrigeration - Freezer, The Mid-Temp Coolers, and Freezer Addition) to provide process cooling and freezing capabilities.  The total amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7664-41-7) contained in the systems is in excess of 10,000 pounds.  The maximum quantity of ammonia held during the calendar year in the Refrigeration - Freezer system is 9,300 lbs. of ammonia, the maximum quantity of ammonia held during the calendar year in the Mid-Temp Coolers system is 16,000 lbs., and the maximum quantity of ammonia held during the calendar year in Freezer Addition is 13,000 lbs. Since an ammonia release from the systems could pose a risk of offsite public and/or environmental impact and the system regulated, the systems are subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's RM program.



-The Prevention Program-



The Accidental Release Prevention Program focuses on efforts at the UNFI Harrisburg facility to contain the refrigerant inside the systems.  The goal is to reduce the risk of injury and promote safer practices at the UNFI Harrisburg facility. The following items are included in the Prevention Program in relation to

requirements for Program Level 3.

1.    Employee Participation (EP)

2.    Process Safety Information (PSI)

3.    Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

4.    Operating Procedures (OP)

5.    Training (TR)

6.    Contractors (C)

7.    Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

8.    Mechanical Integrity (MI)

9.    Hot Work Permit (HW)

10.    Management of Change (MOC)

11.    Incident Investigation (II)

12.    Emergency Planning and Response Program (EP&R)

13.    Compliance Audits (CA)

14.    Trade Secrets (TS) 



Each of these elements play a role in identifying, evaluating, controlling, and preventing potential hazards associated with the ammonia system. Each element is reviewed and updated with frequencies in accordance with regulations on the EPA and OSHA standards.



-Five-Year Accident History-



No reportable accidents have occurred at the UNFI Harrisburg facility in the last 5 years. A sample accident report can be found in the Process Safety Management Files.  



-Emergency Response Program-



The UNFI Harrisburg facility's employees will not respond to accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, and, therefore, an Emergency Response Program is not required. In place of the Emergency Response Program, the facility has developed an Emergency Action Plan and is included in the community's emergency response plan.

The Emergency Action Plan is kept with the Process Safety Management Files.  



-Planned Changes to Improve Safety-



Based upon Contractor recommendations, the facility has begun the following plans to improve safety. These items will be assigned responsible parties, tracked and implemented, or closed out with proper justification, to ensure the facility's ammonia refrigeration systems continue to operate safely.

1.    LEPC/HAZMAT department will participate or be onsite for ammonia additions.
